Why am I hiking the Appalachian Trail? Adventure? Yes. Connect with nature? Yes. See America? Yes. Get
in better shape? Yes. Get away from work? Yes. A bad day of
hiking is better than a good day at work, right?
What it really comes down to, is
something a coworker and friend said on a consulting job last year. The team had various tasks to work on, and I asked my friend â€œWhat
are you going to do today?â€ 
In total seriousness, he replied â€œI
am going to sit in my chair, and watch my life slowly ebb away.â€
LOL! I cracked up. I wrote it down,
along with other pearls of wisdom he has said. But the more I
thought about it, the more I realized I was doing the same. Aren't
most of us doing the same? 
I had recently been taking day hikes
and overnight hikes with some of my buddies at work, and really
enjoying it. It brought back memories from youth of how much I liked
camping and hiking while in the Boy Scouts. And I realized I need to
get back to that. I need to get back to the outdoors. I need to do
something epic. I need to hike the Appalachian Trail!

I didn't think my wife would like me
going off for six months, but I thought she would support me. And I
would miss her. Nights alone. I would miss her every time I saw a
great view or experienced something unique, knowing my description or
even pictures would not do it justice. I would miss sharing those
things with her.
My wife is very close with her 2
brothers and 3 sisters. They talk every day. Every weekend there is
a family event â€“ a birthday, anniversary, graduation, ballgame,
etc. During the week there is dinner here, trivia night there. My
wife cannot be apart from them for long. That is is why I was
stunned, and thrilled, when she told me she would like to hike the
Appalachian Trail with me. 
In her youth she enjoyed camping. It
was mostly car camping, but she enjoys the outdoors. Bizarrely, in
26 years of marriage, we had never gone camping together. 
My new hiking experiences were in
beautiful Idaho. My job was in Boise, and my buddies and I enjoyed
time in the Boise National Forest and in the Sawtooth Mountains. Yellowstone was a half day's drive east. I had to take advantage and
see it while I was out there. I took a week off, and my wife flew
out to visit. We spent the week camping in Yellowstone. It was
great. We decided we should do more camping. So maybe I shouldn't
have been surprised by her desire to join me on the Appalachian
Trail. I don't think she has the same burning desire to climb
Katahdin, and I don't know if she'll last six months on the trail
(will I?), but I am excited that we are going to try it together.

My wife has a nickname for everybody in
her family. She comes up with nicknames for co-workers. She came up
with my trail name - Simple Man. And together, we have tried to find
a trail name for her. Every time she says or does something
memorable, or silly, or funny, it sparks a name, but nothing that
sticks, or that she likes.
For 60 years old, I am in pretty good
shape. My buddies in Idaho were calling me Mountain Goat. (Yes,
that was a contender, but I expect there will be several Mountain
Goats on the trail). My wife, at 57 is pretty healthy, but not in
the condition I am. I can hike faster. She prefers to
have me lead, and says she will just tag-a-long behind me. Tag-a-long. That is her trail name.

I had no intention to journal. I
thought that I would have enough on my plate just getting in mileage,
setting up camp, cooking, resting, keeping my wife engaged. She
likes hiking, but camping is boring when we're alone and don't have
all the luxuries of car camping. Also, carrying a notebook is just
another unnecessary weight in my pack. Or pecking on my smartphone
keyboard would be/is aggravating. But many books and videos
recommend journaling to capture the memories. And so it came to be.

As I mentioned previously, we live in
Dahlonega, and from my house to Gooch Gap is 5 miles. Springer Mtn
is a 40 minute drive. Neels Gap is about the same. I live right in
the middle. That is a blessing.
So here is the plan. When the weather
is not too cold, or too rainy, we are doing a small section â€“ a day
hike or an overnighter. We plan to knock out Georgia before April. In the beginning of April, tentatively April 1st, we will
continue hiking from our last hike and keep going. 
We hope that puts us in or near
Damascus for Trail Days. After that, we hope to make good mileage,
but at the same time don't want to push ourselves so hard we miss the
sights, and the fun. 
Zeros and neros are expected. We like
to sightsee. And given our age, we will probably need rest. I said
I was in good shape, and that refers to muscle tone and cardio. My
weakness is my joints â€“ ankles and hips. Tag-a-long has a bunion,
but an orthopedic surgeon gave her an orthotic, and her Altra Olympus
trail runners provide great cushion. She hasn't had any issues yet
on our shakedown hikes and the first 31 miles of the AT.
We have one side trip planned so far. Tag-a-long has always wanted to see Frank Lloyd Wright's home at
Falling Waters. This happens to be less than 3 hours from Harpers
Ferry. 
In the end, I hope we make Katahdin. If we are don't get far enough fast enough, we could flip flop, but I
hope it doesn't come to that.

As consultants (Tag-a-long does the
same), we can choose to take some time off. My first hikes in Idaho were tough on my feet and my hips. I
used a bookbag for my gear, borrowed a hammock and trekking poles,
and my shoes were Wally World sneakers. My first couple of
overnighters I carried about 35 lbs, with little water and just a few
meals. Each time was great, but I hurt afterwards.
So began the gear hunt. Researching
every day. Darwin. Dixie. Bigfoot. And many more. Kindle
Unlimited. Buying gear. Shakedown hikes. Return gear, give away
gear, buy new gear. More shakedowns. Buy more gear. It's been fun,
but I have spent a LOT of money. And remember that I am buying for
2. 
One word, two syllables: Zpacks.After the trail edit:Â  I recently read a scathing online post about poor customer service from Zpacks, following by several replies from other hikers all railing against the company.Â  While not knowing both sides of the story, I can only sympathize with these hikers.Â  However, my own personal experiences with the company have been consistently phenomenal.Â  The first pack I bought for my wife was the Arc Scout.Â  It is a junior sized pack that did not work for her.Â  I told Zpacks I'd like to return it and buy their Arc Haul pack instead.Â  They had no problem with this.Â  Later on I bought their Altiplex one man tent, but found it too constricting to me, having gotten used to their 3 man Triplex tent.Â  They took back the Altiplex and refunded my money with no issue.Â  On trail my brand new Arc Air pack broke within a week.Â  Zpacks repaired the pack and shipped it back to me on the trail at no cost to me.Â  Meanwhile, I used my Arc Haul pack while I awaited the repair.Â  When a carbon fiber rod broke on the Arc Haul, the shipped a replacement pair of rods to me immediately at no cost to me.Â  Near the end of my thru hike, the Arc Air pack broke again.Â  When I asked Zpacks to repair it a 2nd time, they asked for pictures of the damage.Â  After reviewing the pictures, they decided to send me a brand new pack.Â  My pack had endured about 1800 miles on the AT, and was really beat up, but they gave me a brand new pack anyway.Â  I think that is stellar customer service.

Not all our gear is Zpacks. I have the
Arc Haul and she has the Arc Haul Zip. We are sleeping in a Triplex. She has a Zpacks quilt, but I have a Sierra Designs quilt. We both
have Zpacks Vertex rain jackets. We have Thermarest, Outdoor Vitals, Sawyer, REI, Sea to Summit, and
more. Both wearing Altra Olympus trail runners, although I also own
and like my Altra Lone Peaks. My base weight is 18 lbs, hers is 13
lbs. While our big 3 are very light, we are are carrying lots of (too many) luxuries.
I mentioned my fear is setting up and
tearing down in the rain. In addition to our tent, I also bought a
tarp. The plan is that whenever we set up camp, we first put up the
tarp, and then set up the tent underneath it. I've got cam jams on
the guylines of the tarp, so that we can set it up in a minute. Then
I can relax or setup underneath it, protected from the rain. In the
morning I can tear down as easily. The tarp then stuffs into a side
pocket outside my pack. One side benefit, when it is raining we
won't have the constant patter of rain on the tent, the rain will be
hitting the tarp above. We'll still hear it, but not as loudly. That and earplugs should help me sleep better. And whiskey.

Rain accessories: tarp, rain jacket,
rain mits, kilt, umbrella, water shoes, a pair of waterproof socks. Did I mention I don't like being wet? I would be better off hiking
the PCT. Maybe next year.
My preps will either make it all
bearable, or I'm just gonna have to change my attitude. <smile>

Jan 26 - We started at Amicalola Falls, and registered at the Visitors Center.Â  I am hiker #36, and Tag-a-long is #37.Â  We hiked 7.4 miles to Black Gap shelter.Â  We don't plan to stay in shelters often, given the associated nuisances:Â  crowding, snoring, mice; but since we had the place to ourselves, we made ourselves at home.Â  I set up a tarp to create a partial 4th wall.Â  Tag-a-long tried to make a fire, but everything was damp, and she gave up.Â  The weather had been a bit chilly, but went down into the upper 20s that evening.Â  We slept ok, but a tad bit chilly.Â  The next day was a constant drizzle, with snow predicted.Â  Given the weather, and identifying some comfort issues with her pack, we decided to head home.Â  On the way back to Amicalola we met Tribute, former thru hiker who was helping other newbies get started on their thru hikes.Â  Nice guy, giving back!
Feb 3 - We left Tag-a-long's car at Woody Gap, and drove my truck to Springer Mtn.Â  After hiking to the plaque at the top of Springer, we hiked about 8 miles to Hawk Mountain shelter.Â  Again, we had the place to ourselves.Â  This time I attempted a fire, and my Boy Scout skills proved themselves worthy.Â  We enjoyed the nice fire for a couple of hours before turning in.Â  The temperature was upper 30s this time, and we slept comfortably.Â  In fact, I had to shed my wool socks and thermal bottoms in the middle of the night.Â  The next day was hiked 12 miles to Woody Gap.Â  We were a bit stiff in the calves, but not bad.Â Â 
Feb 17 - We did a day hike from Woody Gap to Neel Gap.Â  Along the way we met Screwball and Arkansas.Â  Nice views from Blood Mountain.

Some gear observations: 
Umbrellas â€“ we have these goofy
umbrellas that sit on your head, but they work great to keep the rain
out of your face, and off your back and pack. And your hands are
free to use your trekking poles, take pictures etc. And they were
only like $12 on Amazon. Very good deal. 
Zpacks Triplex tent â€“ anyone who
camps a lot knows a 3 person tent really fits 2 people, while a two
person tent really fits 1 person, and a 1 person tent is
just a covered sleeping bag. So the 3 person Triplex fits us very
well, is incredibly light at 23 oz, and is super convenient with 2
doorways and 2 vestibules. Of course, it was super expensive. Condensation is an issue, but manageable. We like it.
Dry sacks â€“ even though our packs are
made of basically waterproof Dyneema fabric, and even though we put
our sleeping gear and clothes in a trash compactor bag inside our
packs as an extra layer of protection, water still managed to find
it's was inside. I don't know what we did wrong! So we are buying 2
waterproof dry-sacks each, for our sleeping quilts and for our
clothes, as a third layer of protection. Wet gear sucks!
And finally, our Dyneema tarp. We set
up the tarp first, which is very easily done in a minute using
cam-jams on the guylines, or a few extra minutes if we don't have 4
convenient trees and have to use trekking poles on one or even two
corners. Now, protected from rain, we can set up our tent, or in the
morning tear it down, without getting soaked. Yes, it is redundant. Yes, it adds 10 more ounces to my pack weight. But keeping our
selves and our gear dry is worth it to me. It probably rains 3 out
of 4 days on the trail during the spring. Another hiker who saw us
thought it was a great idea. I may start a new trend!
We leap-frogged some other hikers on
days 2 and 3. Coffee Maker and Deadliner, and Fred (no trail name
yet) were all very nice. At Unicoi Gap, former thru-hiker Bluegrass,
and his lovely wife, provided trail magic to us and other hikers. There was coffee, beer, juice boxes, fruits, chips, fudge rounds,
pretzels, and more, plus great conversation and hiking advice. At
Dicks Creek Gap, someone left a 12 pack of beer forÂ  hikers. There
were 3 left, so Coffee Maker and Deadliner had one each, and
Tag-a-long and I split the last one. Tag-a-long managed to yogi some
water and bananas from a family that were day hiking. Yogi-ing (a la
Yogi the bear) is getting someone to give you stuff, without begging
outright. She taught them how to be trail angels and give trail
magic. Clever girl!

For anyone who reads our journal, I apologize for this untimely and delayed notice that Tag-a-long and I decided to suspend our hike due to the virus.Â  After arriving home, some good contract work we can do from home came in, so we have changed our hike plan to 2021.Â  I am jealous of those still out there, and don't blame them at all for sticking to it.Â  The stats are coming in now, and Stanford U antibody studies showing that mortality rates are not much different than the 2017-2018 flu season, and most people have very little risk of serious illness.Â  None-the-less, the elderly and those with underlying health issues need to be especially careful (as always), so I don't feel bad about canceling our hike.Â  See you next year!EDIT (2021) - Ha!Â  Sure didn't see how that was gonna play out!Â  There is plenty of contention about how much of the numbers are real and how much is hype, but covid has been serious, and has seriously sucked!

Our hike cut short last year by covid, my wife and I came home to Dahlonega.Â  We both got work from home consulting jobs, and put off the hike until 2021.Â  Due to some family issues, my wife will not be hiking this year.Â  I'm going solo.Â  In a way, covid worked out well for me, and even though I was envious of those still on the trail, the time off gave me the opportunity to fine tune my gear and train my body for the challenge.Â  I am stronger, my base weight is 5 lbs lighter, and I have more experience on the trail.Â Â 
My wife gave me the trail name of Simple Man last year, but I've heard from Crusoe that he has crossed paths with another wearing my trail name and since he is ahead of me, I'll always be #2.Â  It has led me on a quest for a new name, and open to being named on the trail.Â  As luck would have it, successful thru hiker and book author, Ultra Hiking Girl, has bestowed me with the name Kitty Hawk.Â  In our emails we discussed our pets, as well as trail prep, and she gave the nameÂ Kitty because I have two cats I love, Hawk because I have dialed in my gear and pay attention to detail like a hawk.Â  Shout out to Ultra, who is hiking the AT again this year and on the trail now.

After the hike
edit â€“ My pack is discussed in another edit. My tent worked well
the entire hike. I seldom had condensation issues, and used a microfiber towel to wipe down the interior when needed.Â  I lost a couple of stakes, and replaced them with .90 cent Walmart stakes.Â  The tri-sided stake generally worked better than the hook style stake, but it was convenient to have both.Â  I sent the tarp home because it didn't really help
that much. I was lucky that I never had to set up in the rain until
New Hampshire, and only once more after that. Luck and timing. I
did cut my air mattress down to 60 inches length, following
instructions on several youtube videos. It worked well.Â  My luxury Thermarest air pump was awesome, and some hikers said I could make money renting it to others.Â  In 2200 miles, I only changed the batteries once.Â  My extra large Sea to Summit pillow was a luxury that I appreciated throughout my hike.

The Zpacks 20 degree quilt and the Enlightened Equipment 50 degree quilt both worked well.Â  On the few nights that it got down into the 20s, then I needed both to stay toasty warm.Â  Fortunately, I carried both from Franklin to Damascus, an extra 12.5 ounces.Â  After Damascus, the 50 degree quilt was plenty most nights, and when it was a bit cooler I just slept wearing my puffy.Â  I switched back to the 20 degree in Hanover, and never had any issue with it.

I ditched
my stove and cold soaked for a while, and then I quit cold soaking
too. My food was restricted to protein shakes and food that was
edible straight from the package. It was not healthy, but I packed
in a lot of calories and kept my weight up.Â  When I did use my cold soak container to make ramen noodles, there was oily residue from the flavor pack, that I cleaned using dirt.Â  Hiker Truckstop called me a real mountain man when he saw me do that.

I kept most of
my rain gear, but changed from the cheap Amazon umbrella to a Six
Moon Designs umbrella. The Six Moon Designs umbrella was much more
durable. Using the umbrella, I seldom needed my rain jacket. If it
rained hard, the umbrella plus the rain kilt did a good job. The
rain jacket did make a good windbreaker. The water proof socks did
not hold up. I had two pair. One pair quickly got a hole in it, and
the other pair still let water through after a couple hours.Â 

My Moto G Power phone was
phenomenally good! The battery life lived up to it's reputation as
the longest in the industry. I went six days thru the Smokies on a
single charge by using airplane mode and turning it off at night. Also, I dropped the phone into 3 feet of water in Massachusetts, and
it continued working without a hitch. Kudos to Motorola! I did get
a 5000 mAh battery backup along the way, when I started using the
phone more (calls, texting, music) and to recharge a USB handheld fan
I bought. I know, talk about a luxury item! But it was super hot in
Pennsylvania and beyond. All the guys thought it was hilarious, but
I think they were jealous.

nicer to start my day in, rather than the wet, muddy socks I wore
yesterday.Â  The Injinji Nuwool socks did not last very long, but regular Injinji socks lasted the entire hike.Â  Darn Tuff socks also lasted throughout.Â  The wool beanie was nice, but slipped off every time while sleeping.Â  The balaclava worked ok, but sleeping in my hooded puffy was best on the few nights it was really cold.Â  Wool gloves and rain mitts were good at keeping my fingers warm, but I did not need them after Tennessee.

I switched from Altra Lone Peaks to the more cushioned Altra Olympus on day four, after experiencing knee pain.Â  I stayed with the Olympus throughout, finishing my hike in my fourth pair. I also used a Dr Schols insert for runner's knee. This combo helped
my knee recover from initial injury at the beginning (discussed
ahead) and held up throughout some seriously tough terrain up North. I did have continual though mild issues with my Achilles tendons. I
don't know if this was caused by or increased by the zero drop shoe. 

The Zpacks Multipack worked well as a fanny pack.Â  I switched out the Petzl lamp for a Walmart lamp that was 2 ounces heavier, but was much brighter. The Petzl worked fine in my tent, but did not put out much illumination for night hiking, which I did a few times.Â  The Walmart lamp did burn up some batteries, so I had to carry spares.Â  I almost never used my sunglasses.Â  They might have been useful keeping bugs out of my eyes, which is an important issue in later entries!Â  If you are comfortable changing diapers, then touching yourself down there is ok to ensure a satisfactory cleansing after using a trail bidet, followed of course with hand sanitizer.Â  Not carrying TP saved space in my pack, and reduced trail impact as well.Â  I used only 1 bandaid.Â  I used lots of Ibuprophen and Naproxin (Alleve).Â  I carried Doxycycline for Lyme Disease and it ending up being a crucial luxury item.Â  I, and several other hikers got Lyme Disease, and getting a prescription from my doctor, and filling it to be able to carry the pills with me, saved me significant time and money!Â  I highly recommend this!

Hanging a bear bag on a tree - I didn't do it.Â  If the shelter had a bear box, or a pole with cables, I used that.Â  At first I used an Ursack, but decided that even that 1/2 pound was too much weight.Â  I put my food in a smell proof Loksak, and then put that bag inside another Loksak just to be sure.Â  I also did not cook, putting aromas into the air to attract a bear.Â  I figured a bear would much rather go after the uncontested and poorly hung bear bags of other hikers, than mess with my tent which had little or no food smell.Â  I never saw or heard a bear.Â  Some of you will criticize me, but by the time I got to New England, a majority of hikers I spoke with admitted that often did not hang their food.

As I said in my first entry last year, one day I asked a co-worker what he was doing (meaning - what was he working on that day) and he replied "I'm going to sit in my chair and watch my life slowly ebb away."Â  That sad reply made me think about how I spent my time, and I realized that I should spend more of it outdoors, hiking, camping, seeing nature, keeping in shape, seeing the country.Â  My wife also enjoys these things, our child is grown, our house is paid off, nothing tying us down...so why not?Â Â 
The more hiking I did, the more I was drawn to the idea of a thru hike of the Appalachian Trail.Â  I live 4.7 miles from the trail, and only 30-40 minutes from Springer Mountain where the trail begins in Georgia.Â  It's a no brainer.Â  It is said that a bad day on the trail is better than a good day at the office.Â  I am going to put that to the test.
My wife is not going this time (family issues she's taking care of) so I'm on my own.Â  She is worried that I will be attacked by a bear, or bitten by a rattlesnake, or get Lyme disease, or fall off a cliff.Â  But it will take a lot more than any of these to stop me!
I have watched many hundreds of hiking videos on Youtube, and greatly appreciate all the information other hikers have shared, but the idea of holding up a selfie stick while I walk, and then spend time editing and posting videos is just not my thing.Â  I don't mind writing, so this journal will provide my trail memories when I am old(er) and senile, and it gives my family, friends, and well wishers the opportunity to keep track of my adventure.Â  There are some photos from our hiking attempt last year, and I will post many more photos going forward.Â  Previous entries detail experiences and gear and hint at some of my insanity, and future entries will be covering new experiences and greater insanity.Â  Please feel free to ask questions, comment or make recommendations.Â  You are my virtual friends and family.After the trail edit:Â  Ha Ha!Â  I did get Lyme disease, but that didn't stop me!

Actually, I am not.Â  As long as I've got something to eat, I don't care much about what it is.Â  I can eat the same thing everyday without much complaint.Â  And I don't have a sweet tooth.Â  After about 4 years of being a flexitarian, as they call it, a vegetarian that occasionally gets a hankering for a hot dog, I've been full vegan for a year now.Â  At 61, with no medications of any kind, my blood pressure is 110/70, my cholesterol has dropped from 270 to 185, and I am in great shape.Â  My only issues are in the joints, and my current diet and stretching routines have greatly reduced if not eliminated issues in my knees and hips.
So here is my meal plan on the trail:
Coffee when I wake up on a chilly morning.Â  I've always been hard core, but I've switched to decaf for the past couple months to hopefully improve my sleep cycle.Â  I'll need good rest to recover each night.Â  In the summer I may skip this and go straight to breakfast.
Breakfast - morning smoothie with a meal shake (it's a vegan protein shake with added fat and carbs) with powdered soy milk, with a scoop of Amazing Greens.Â  Quick and easy so I can get on the trail.Â  700 cal.
2nd Breakfast - another meal smoothie, but swap the Amazing Greens for oatmeal, hemp seeds, raisins, and a dash of cinnamon.Â  1200 cal.
Snacks/lunch/snacks - throughout the day will be Pro Bars, Clif Bars, etc and gorp.Â  And peanut butter in squeeze pouches.Â  Avg 1000 cal.
Dinner - a blend of ramen, couscous, hemp and chia seeds, cranberries, powdered peanut butter, and nutritional yeast - may be cooked or may be cold soaked.Â  1100 cal.
I'm shooting for 4000 calories per day to start.Â  I know many people don't have much hunger initially, but I have been walking 6-8 miles or more a day since last May.Â  I'm halfway to hiker hunger already.Â  In town I'll be looking for Taco Bell, impossible burgers at Burger King, Subway veggie sandwiches, or any veggie options at restaurants.Â  I'm going to have drop boxes sent to locations with meager resupply options.Â  I can't guarantee that I won't cave in for some pizza (mmmm pizzaaaaa) or BBQ (mmmm BBQuuuuu) but I am going to try to stick to my vegan diet.
One more week till I hit the trail.
BTW, I only weigh 155 lbs, so I don't have much to lose.Â Â

edit: The Arc Air pack is very nice, and I like it even better than
the Arc Haul. It really keeps the pack off of your back, so less
sweat. It is smaller, lighter, and more waterproof than my Arc Haul. I did not use a pack liner inside, or pack cover outside, and never
had any water issues with my gear. By the end of the trail I refused
to carry more than 2 days of food, requiring more frequent
resuppling, but that kept my pack weight at 20 lbs or less. 
I did have a
problem with the pack. It has two curved carbon fiber rods that give
the pack it's shape, the curve keeping the pack off of your back. The rods are held in place by very thick material at the bottom. Within a week, one of the rods broke through the fabric, and then dug
into my back. Extremely uncomfortable. My sweetheart of a wife,
brought me my Arc Haul to Franklin, NC, and took back the Arc Air. She mailed it to Zpacks, and they repaired the pack, returning it to
me in Damascus VA. All was good, until somewhere in New England the
other rod would slip out of the sleeve where it is inserted . I
would, with great difficulty, push it back into place, but it didn't
take long for it slip out again, so not providing the proper framing
on that side. Then, in Maine, the first rod broke through it's
fabric at the bottom again. This time, I removed the rod altogether,
creating a semi-frameless pack. This worked ok for the remainder of
my hike. 
Now here is
the good part. When I got home, I told Zpacks about the problem. I
wanted to return it for repair under their warranty. In addition, I
was willing to pay for some other maintenance, because after 1800
miles, the mesh pocket was torn up, and the Dyneema was delaminating
in some places. They requested pictures of the rod issue, and after
review decided to send me a brand new pack! They said that if the
first repair did not fix the problem, and 2nd repair
probably would do any better. So my new pack is on the way. Wow! Now that is great customer service!

Are all for naught!Â  I did all the stretching, supplements, and 20 mile day hikes, so that I was READY to hike 20 miles a day from the get go.Â  My left knee said otherwise.Â  I put in 17 miles on Day 1, but should have stopped at 15 (or sooner).Â  I stealth camped about a mile past Gooch Gap.Â  Two Alleve's and an Ibuprofen for good measure, allowed me to make 7 miles on Day 2 to Lance Creek Campsite.Â  It was very crowded, but since the weather was perfect with no chance of rain, many of us cowboy camped (open air, no tent) so that we managed to fit.Â  Today was another short day of 7 miles to Neels Gap.Â  Some of us couldn't sleep, so we got up at about 4:00 AM to night hike and see the sunrise on Blood Mountain.Â  Tough climb in the dark, and on a bum knee, but I did it.Â  Hopefully a few short days will let the knee shape up.Â  So many nice people, just a few I met: Kelly, Grace, Andrew, Faith, Mijal, Fern, Kaila, James, Stephanie and her dog Huck, Colleen, Kevin, and Ed. I decided to take a zero (zero miles hiked) after my knee stiffened and swelled.Â  So today's thoughts are observations on the mix of hikers I met.Â  In a youtube video I saw a couple of weeks ago, the hiker stated he had seen a number of female hikers, but at his campsite that night, all sixteen were men, with about two thirds being younger and a third being older (retired or nearly so).Â  In my first couple of days I have seen different ratios.Â  I think it has been closer to 50-50 male/female.Â  It could be 60-40 or somewhere there about, but a lot of women.Â  Many older hikers, but I think the number is closer to 80% younger, i.e. 20s and 30s.Â  Older tended to be 50s and 60s, and a very few 70s.Â  All of these numbers are guesses.Â Â 
In the first three days, I spent time hiking and talking with 7 people (all younger), and talked with a few more in camp (some younger, some older).Â  Two, myself and Kelly (Kelly Hays Hikes), do contract work, making it easier to take this 6 month sabbatical.Â  Three experienced job dissatisfaction or burnout, and were considering career modifications or changes after they completed their hike.Â  One man was retired.Â  One woman, after some years in the Navy, was working out some post deployment stress.Â  I heard from my friends that they had heard similar from two other former service members.Â  Four people I talked with had given up their apartments, or sold their home, and put all of their belongings in storage.Â  All corners of the continental US were represented.Â  As best I could tell there were only two foreigners, a young woman from England (who has almost no accent) and an older woman with a German, or Dutch accent, or something like that.
Most people were very social, and happy to be on trail.Â  There are some introverted hikers, who have to drawn into discussion, but most hikers are glib.Â  I did meet an older man who was a bit rough, somewhat of a loner, and carried a knife on his hip belt.Â  I don't want to judge a book by it's cover, but he did not fit the typical AT hiker profile.Â Â 
Other than this one exception, everyone was friendly and welcoming (and to be fair, the rough guy was friendly).Â  All are equal, regardless of age, sex, income, career, or motivations.Â  Everyone experiences the same trail and the same trials.Â  There was zero political or religious discussion.Â Â

Let's talk about the saying "the trail provides".Â  You hear this all time out here.Â  When you are in need, something appears or occurs that resolves your issue.Â  You could be out of water, and the guide book says no water for 6 more miles, and there has been a drought and the last source was dry...and then out of the blue you come upon a cache of water provided for hikers.Â  The trail provides.

Or your tired and discouraged, and it's been raining all day, and you wish you were in town, but the next town is 20 miles away.Â  You cross a forest road.Â  You will only be at that place for a few seconds, but at that veryÂ  moment a total stranger drives up, stops and asks if you need help, and then takes you 20 miles to town.Â  The trail provides.Â  ( True story, as told to me by 2 hikers).

Or you've been wearing a hiking shoe that just doesn't fit right, and over time has been causing you serious pain.Â  You've decided you're going to have to get off trail, so that you can shuttle to a town with a good outfitter, where you can get better shoes.Â  It will be time consuming and expensive.Â  But soon after this decision has been made, the trail leads past on old schoolhouse datedÂ  1912.Â  It is maintained by a nearby church, who have a register inside for visitors to sign (mostly thru hikers).Â  Out of curiosity, you step inside to check it out, see the register, but then see, underneath the table the register is on, a pair of hiking shoes in decent condition, IN YOUR SIZE!Â  The trail provides.Â  (True story per the hiker, and he showed me the shoes).

Make of it what you will, but most thru hikers have experienced something like this one or more times, and most believe the saying...the trail provides.

Well folks, it's almost over.Â  Sorry the last entry was so short.Â  I ran out of time.Â Â Bill, if you're starting your reading here, I recommend going back to April and reading chronologically.Â  Some things won't make much sense otherwise.So the bug in the eye contest continues to draw feedback.Â  Helpful suggestions have been made and either tried and discarded, or duly ignored.Â  I do appreciate the concern.Â  As it stands, left eye still 2, right eye now 14.Â  It continues to defy logic.On a side note, whenever there is a cold morning, or a lot of wind, my right eye tears up.Â  Not the left eye.Â  If this was a recent occurrence only, I might blame the bug attacks on the right eye.Â  I think, however, that the tearing goes back prior to this thru hike.Â  Could bugs have been targeting my right eye for years without me knowing?Â Â Pitfall and I arrived in Monson today.Â  Monson is the last town the trail passes near before Mt Katahdin.Â  We have to traverse the 100 mile wilderness, ending near Baxter State Park.Â  Then about 9 miles to the base of Katahdin, with a 5.2 mile climb to the summit.Â  Of course, once we have achieved our goal, we have to climb down.Â  Katahdin is a tough climb, of course.Pitfall has rented a house for us to stay in the town of Millinocket, where we can decompress, and do a bit of sightseeing at Bar Harbor and Acadia National Park.Â  Then I have to figure out how to get home.Â Â I have enjoyed this adventure very much, but admit that I am tired, and look forward to going home.Â  Weather permitting, this adventure will be completed within one week.Â  I'll have more detail and some epic pics to share then.

At long last, the trail has been hiked.Â  I was going to say the journey completed, but I am still a long way from home.

The 100 mile wilderness begins with a sign that warns there is no place to get supplies or help, and recommends carrying at least 10 days of food.Â  That makes sense.Â  Many people hiking this section are day or weekend hikers, who are challenged to hike even 10 miles a day.Â  Even Sobo hikers are just starting their thru hike, and haven't built up their trail legs yet. But us Nobos are hiking professionals who can knock out the 100 miles in 3 to 5 days.Â Â 

I hiked the wilderness in 4 days.Â  19 miles day one, after a late start, over mostly nice terrain.Â  Day two was tougher, with a lot of climbs.Â  However, along the way we were surprised by trail magic.Â  As we hiked along there was a sign not just announcing trail magic, but it specifically was addressed to Kitty Hawk and Pitfall.Â  Who could that be?Â  Who knew where we were, and would come all the way out here?Â  It was spooky.Â  Turns out Sherpa and Trail Mom knew when we entered the wilderness, and guestimated when we would arrive at a place they could get to.Â  The fed us, and every other hiker who came through.Â  It was such a beautiful thing!

Days three and four were (relatively) pleasant.Â  We did 31 miles and then 26 miles into Abol Bridge.Â  There were spots where we got views of Katahdin.Â  K-town, the Big K.Â  The end was in sight, and it was majestic.

At Abol Bridge there is a campground and a camp store.Â  I immediately downed the required 2 sodas to restore my blood sugar levels.Â  It was too late to enter Baxter State Park, and there is a sign-up and permit process required to hike the mountain.Â  So we had to either get to the nearest town, Millinocket, which is 30 minutes by car, or pay an exhorbitant $30 to tent at the campsite.Â  Being older, financially solid, and tired, Pitfall and I paid for a campsite.

We saw 3 young hikers, a guy (Goat) and 2 gals (Rocket and Slayer), nearby with a couple of six packs, debating their options, and what it was going to cost them.Â  After conversation revealed they were good kids, I offered to pay their fees to tent in the campsite, in exchange for some of their beers.Â  They happily agreed, and bought a couple more 6 packs to ensure Pitfall and I were well taken care of.Â Â 

Since we had a merry group and plenty of beer, I decided to buy some firewood, and made my first campfire on my thru hike.Â  We had a great time.

After breakfast the next day, Pitfall and I said our farewells, and hitched into Millinocket, because the weather forecast was rain and thunderstorms for the next 2 days.Â  It is a very bad idea to climb Katahdin in that kind of weather.Â  We changed our summit day from Sunday, Aug 29 to Tuesday, Aug 30.

You recall that Pitfall rented a house in Millinocket for the week of Aug 29 to Sept 4.Â  We went to the house, which was large, nice and comfortable.Â  Two days of rest were just what the doctor ordered.

Along the way we invited some hikers to come stay with us if they needed a place.Â  Slayer was one, and a gal I met twice in Virginia, named Kiddo, who we were constantly leapfrogging in Maine was the other.Â  Kiddo was on her 2nd AT thru hike, having done it 10 years prior.Â  What I did not know, until she took us up on our offer, was that she also hiked the Pacific Crest Trail and the Continental Divide Trail, and so was a triple crowner.Â  In addition, she is a wilderness guide at Glacier National Park, has hiked in the Alps and New Zealand, and she guessed she has hiked 18,000 or more trail miles.Â  That is incredible.Â  She is also a talented pianist and guitar player, with a beautiful voice.

On the big day, Kiddo asked to join us on our summit climb.Â  We were glad to have her company.Â  It was a challenge to keep up with her, but Pitfall and I met the challenge.Â  It was a sunny day.Â  The first 2 miles up were hard work, at the adrenaline fueled pace we set, but not crazy.Â  The next two miles were serious and difficult rock climbing.Â  The final mile was a rock scramble in a foggy haze, as the mountain decided to shroud it's crown from the sun.Â Â 

It was cold and windy at the top, despite it being sunny and warm below.Â  There was no view.Â  But the famous sign at the summit was there to greet us, and we took many pictures.Â  I was happy to have achieved my goal, at long last, but not overwhelmed by my happiness, nor sad it was over. I felt that I should feel more, but maybe, being 61, I didn't need to feel like I had a life changing experience.Â  I felt from the beginning of this hike that I did not expect or want to change my life or my career or my perspectives.Â  I just wanted to do something epic.Â  I hiked 2193 trail miles, and who knows how many off trail miles, walking from Georgia to Maine.Â  I saw beautiful landscapes, and wildlife, and met many wonderful people. It has been a good hike.

If I write a book, I'll need an epilogue.

What next?Â  Many hikers asked if I will hike the Pacific Crest Trail, or some other significant trail?Â  Maybe.Â  Early on I enthusiastically said yes, I will hike the PCT.Â  But now I'm not sure.Â  I'm tired.Â  I miss my wife and I miss home and my simple routines there.Â  I want to play my new Taylor guitar.Â  But I don't feel quite ready to go home.Â  My nephew Cris and niece Karina go to school in Boston, and my sister is there right now as well.Â  I would love to see them.Â  I have never been to Boston.Â  Pitfall and MoJoe both live near Boston and have invited me to visit.

Truckstop also invited me to visit him in Maine, but he has not yet completed his hike.

I still have numerous friends on the trail, and I would love to see them, maybe surprising them with trail magic.Â  Some have even asked if I would hike with them for a bit.Â  Maybe I would enjoy that?
